I'm changing it now that it only uploads the compressed version. Downloading and extracting is very simple with code like this:
```Pkg.PlatformEngines.download_verify_unpack("<https://symbolcache.julia-vscode.org/store/v1/packages/A/AndExport_4484d908-372d-4f90-b90b-0ec97f005b8c/v1.0.1_ebc539a19124dd3f67087d50376adc010c577536.tar.gz>", nothing, folderpath_where_you_want_the_extracted_file)```

elements.text: I'm changing it now that it only uploads the compressed version. Downloading and extracting is very simple with code like this:
Pkg.PlatformEngines.download_verify_unpack("
", nothing, folderpath_where_you_want_the_extracted_file)

messages.text: You just need to call `Pkg.PlatformEngines.probe_platform_engines!()` _once_ in the process that is going to do the downloading before you can make calls to `download_verify_unpack`

Pkg.PlatformEngines.probe_platform_engines!()
once
in the process that is going to do the downloading before you can make calls to
download_verify_unpack

messages.text: I think the workaround for the file limit that was mentioned on that github issue for Azure Static Web Sites seems to work, so I think that might no longer be a problem. I think right now we have about 6.5k cache files up in the cloud. In about an hour we should be done with the first pass that uploaded the latest two versions per package. What is not working yet is the detection on when something went wrong, so I don't have a sense at the moment how many indexing attempts failed.  That will be the next thing I'll try to fix.

elements.text: I think the workaround for the file limit that was mentioned on that github issue for Azure Static Web Sites seems to work, so I think that might no longer be a problem. I think right now we have about 6.5k cache files up in the cloud. In about an hour we should be done with the first pass that uploaded the latest two versions per package. What is not working yet is the detection on when something went wrong, so I don't have a sense at the moment how many indexing attempts failed.  That will be the next thing I'll try to fix.

messages.text: I now generate and upload a `tar.gz` file even if the indexing failed, so there should always be something to be downloaded _if_ the indexer has tried to index a given package/version ever.

elements.text: I now generate and upload a
tar.gz
file even if the indexing failed, so there should always be something to be downloaded
if
the indexer has tried to index a given package/version ever.

messages.text: In the extracted file, if the indexing worked, there will be a `.jstor` file. If it didn't work, there will be a `.unavailable` file instead. The latter essentially signals to the client `I don't and I won't have a cached file for this, so don't try to download this again`

elements.text: In the extracted file, if the indexing worked, there will be a
.jstor
file. If it didn't work, there will be a
.unavailable
file instead. The latter essentially signals to the client
I don't and I won't have a cached file for this, so don't try to download this again

messages.text: Whereas, if the client tries to download a given archive, and gets an invalid URL error, it should try again the next time, because that essentially means that the indexer simply hasn't tried to index that particular package/version combo yet.

elements.text: Whereas, if the client tries to download a given archive, and gets an invalid URL error, it should try again the next time, because that essentially means that the indexer simply hasn't tried to index that particular package/version combo yet.

messages.text: The whole UTF8/UTF16 story in the LSP is a mess. I think (if I remember correctly) all indices are always based on UTF16, but the transport level protocol is UTF8. Or something like that

messages.text: Hello everyone! I’m Tony, a junior at UC Berkeley. I’ve worked on several past projects on Julia such as the plotgallery with <@U68UUUFPS>, and I’m excited to join the VS Code dev team! I’m familiar with Javascript, Typescript, and React. I’m new here so if there is anything that I need to know or any exciting projects that need people to work on, feel free to ping me.

elements.text: Hello everyone! I’m Tony, a junior at UC Berkeley. I’ve worked on several past projects on Julia such as the plotgallery with

, and I’m excited to join the VS Code dev team! I’m familiar with Javascript, Typescript, and React. I’m new here so if there is anything that I need to know or any exciting projects that need people to work on, feel free to ping me.

messages.text: Hiya, welcome!

elements.text: Hiya, welcome!

messages.text: Yes, so I thought this semester it would make more sense if Tony just hangs out with all of us here, rather than the two of us just doing our own thing :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yes, so I thought this semester it would make more sense if Tony just hangs out with all of us here, rather than the two of us just doing our own thing

messages.text: Makes sense. Hi Tony!

elements.text: Makes sense. Hi Tony!

messages.text: Nice, sounds good

elements.text: Nice, sounds good

messages.text: Have you two got some plans cooked up that will use Tony's particular skills?

elements.text: Have you two got some plans cooked up that will use Tony's particular skills?

messages.text: Here is one idea for a project: Tony reworked the plot gallery a while ago. Back then the design was that the whole plot view was replaced with a two part thing that looked a little like PowerPoint: on the left we had a list of thumbnails of all the plots, on the right the currently active one was displayed larger. I still like the general idea, but I think now that we can place arbitrary views into the sidebar, I would probably design this differently. In particular, I think we could leave the existing plot view as is, but simply add a thumbnail view of all the plots that exist as a view in the sidebar. Clicking on one of the thumbnails there would switch the active plot in the plot view etc. So I think that could be a nice project?

elements.text: Here is one idea for a project: Tony reworked the plot gallery a while ago. Back then the design was that the whole plot view was replaced with a two part thing that looked a little like PowerPoint: on the left we had a list of thumbnails of all the plots, on the right the currently active one was displayed larger. I still like the general idea, but I think now that we can place arbitrary views into the sidebar, I would probably design this differently. In particular, I think we could leave the existing plot view as is, but simply add a thumbnail view of all the plots that exist as a view in the sidebar. Clicking on one of the thumbnails there would switch the active plot in the plot view etc. So I think that could be a nice project?

messages.text: That does sound good

elements.text: That does sound good

messages.text: <@U01L42VSVBJ>: <@U6BNE7LTZ> just added a documentation browser as a sideview panel in this PR <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/1458>, so that should show how one can add an webview to the sidebar and he can probably also point you to the relevant documentation.

messages.text: My gut feeling right now is that if we have the thumbnail view and the actual plot view in two different webviews, it might be simpler to not use react this time around, just to keep things simple. In fact, I think with this design we would not have to change anything about the existing plot gallery view/implementation, essentially we would just add another, separate UI element that makes it easier to switch through plots.

elements.text: My gut feeling right now is that if we have the thumbnail view and the actual plot view in two different webviews, it might be simpler to not use react this time around, just to keep things simple. In fact, I think with this design we would not have to change anything about the existing plot gallery view/implementation, essentially we would just add another, separate UI element that makes it easier to switch through plots.

messages.text: Yep agree on holding back the web stuff. I went through the crash report list and tidied up the easy ones today. There are two sets of stackoverflow reports, one from CSTParser (these are really bizzare and limited to a single user) that I may have pushed a fix for. The other group are the ones from LS/SL that we def know about. I think I have a way forward on these but it could take a week or so, so lets not wait for that.
